instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2877: What is 820-2877? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP1V05_S5: What is PP1V05_S5? PP1V05_S5 is a 1.05v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. On 2008-2009 15” and 17” Macbook boards, this often gets stuck at 0.3v due to a bad C7771 capacitor. .

threads.title: [SOLVED] No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hello,
Sorry for my bad English. 
I have a problem with an older <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Pro and I hope somebody can help me with it. The device was water damaged. However, I couldn't find any proof of water inside! I checked the Power Rails and noticed that everything including <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is ok. But the first S3 Rail (<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>) isn’t. It's reading is 0V! I checked the beginning of the circuit and noted that the ENTRIP signal for <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> is 0V. Pin 2 on <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> is 3,3V. That’s why this Transistor sends the ENTRIP to ground I think. I followed this path and saw that this ENABEL come from a Transistor which is closed by <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, which is also 0V on this machine. There is no Short on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>. I've already checked the input and output signals of the PCH which only confuse me. I can't find any other S5 Rails needed for the PCH to turn on (like <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S5</SIGNAL> on other boards do). I'm stuck at this point. I hope you can understand my bad English. It would be really great if someone could give me a hint where I have to Look next.
Tanks!

threads.title: [SOLVED] No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: This is a core 2 duo board, so, no PCH on it......  It does not power on by itself.....  Short <RESISTOR>R5015</RESISTOR> pads to power on the board....

threads.title: [SOLVED] No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hello,
thank you for your answer. I´ll try it tomorrow and hope it will work again. This would mean that the keyboard is damaged and i´m sorry that i wasted your time. if not i´ll let you know. By the way: How can i find out which pads i have to short on which board to turn it on?

threads.title: [SOLVED] No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Bad keyboard is pretty common on this mac.....

[url]http://www.insidemylaptop.com/turn-on-macbook-pro-laptop-without-power-button-locating-power-on-pads/[/url]

threads.title: [SOLVED] No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I really can not believe that I was so dumb. Thats all. It´s working again! Just by shorting the pads. Thank you so much for your help!
Have a nice Day!
Best regards,
Felix
